name: Fulfillment Theology
shortDescription: Theological framework asserting that Jesus Christ fulfills the prophecies, types, and promises of the Hebrew Scriptures, central to Matthew's Gospel
longDescription: Fulfillment Theology is the interpretive framework, especially prominent in Matthew's Gospel, that presents Jesus as the culmination of God's promises to Israel throughout the Hebrew Scriptures. Matthew employs a distinctive 'fulfillment formula' - 'This was done to fulfill what was spoken by the prophet' - at least twelve times, systematically connecting events in Jesus' life to specific Old Testament prophecies. This approach demonstrates that Jesus is not a break from Judaism but its intended completion: the virgin birth fulfills Isaiah 7:14, Bethlehem fulfills Micah 5:2, Egypt fulfills Hosea 11:1, Galilee fulfills Isaiah 9:1-2, healings fulfill Isaiah 53:4, triumphal entry fulfills Zechariah 9:9, and the betrayal price fulfills Zechariah 11:12-13. Beyond direct prophecy, fulfillment theology recognizes typological patterns: Jesus as the new Moses (both threatened as infants, called from Egypt, giving law from a mountain), the new Israel (passing through water, tempted in wilderness, choosing twelve), and the new David (royal lineage, shepherd-king). The five discourses of Matthew mirror the five books of Torah, presenting Jesus' teachings as the authoritative interpretation of God's will. This theology served Jewish-Christian communities by validating their faith in Jesus as Messiah while maintaining continuity with their ancestral heritage. It remains foundational for Christian biblical interpretation, apologetics, and understanding of salvation history as a unified narrative culminating in Christ.

linguistic.transliteration: pleroo (verb: to fulfill, complete, fill up)

alternativeNames.name: Promise-Fulfillment Schema
alternativeNames.meaning: Pattern of divine promise and historical realization

etymology.meaning: To fill completely, accomplish, bring to completion
etymology.derivation: From Greek 'pleroo' (to fill) - used 90 times in NT, 16 times in Matthew

geographical.originContext: Developed in Jewish-Christian communities, especially Antioch, Syria

firstAttestation.description: Systematic use of fulfillment formula in Matthew's Gospel

temporal.culturalPeriod: Apostolic Era / Early Church (1st-2nd century CE)

literaryReferences.significance: Primary expression of fulfillment theology with formula citations
Uses fulfillment language, especially in passion narrative
Develops typological fulfillment of priesthood and sacrifice

literaryReferences.author: Justin Martyr
literaryReferences.significance: Earliest systematic Christian apologetic using fulfilled prophecy

fulfillmentFormula.name: The Fulfillment Formula
fulfillmentFormula.description: Matthew's distinctive introductory phrase for prophecy citations
fulfillmentFormula.greekText: hina/hopos plerothe to rhethen hypo tou prophetou
fulfillmentFormula.translation: This was done that what was spoken by the prophet might be fulfilled

categories.description: Patterns of God's action repeated in Christ
Deeper meaning in Scripture beyond original context

torahParallelism.name: Five Discourses / Five Books of Moses
torahParallelism.description: Matthew structures Jesus' teaching into five major discourses mirroring the Pentateuch, presenting Jesus as the new Moses giving new Torah

parallels.theme: New creation, new humanity, kingdom ethics
Calling and sending, mission and persecution

jesusAsNewMoses.name: Jesus as New Moses Typology
jesusAsNewMoses.description: Matthew systematically presents Jesus as the greater Moses
parallels: Birth threatened by king who kills infants (Pharaoh/Herod)
Gave law from mountain (Sinai/Sermon on Mount)

davidicFulfillment.name: Davidic Covenant Fulfillment
davidicFulfillment.description: Jesus fulfills promises to David of eternal kingdom
elements: Born in Bethlehem, city of David

fulfillmentQuotations.description: The twelve major fulfillment formula quotations in Matthew

quotations.content: Behold, a virgin shall be with child, and shall bring forth a son, and they shall call his name Emmanuel
And thou Bethlehem, in the land of Juda, art not the least among the princes of Juda: for out of thee shall come a Governor
Out of Egypt have I called my son
quotations.event: Return from Egypt after Herod's death

quotations.content: In Rama was there a voice heard, lamentation, and weeping, and great mourning, Rachel weeping for her children
He shall be called a Nazarene
The land of Zabulon, and the land of Nephthalim... The people which sat in darkness saw great light
Himself took our infirmities, and bare our sicknesses
Behold my servant, whom I have chosen; my beloved, in whom my soul is well pleased
By hearing ye shall hear, and shall not understand; and seeing ye shall see, and shall not perceive
I will open my mouth in parables; I will utter things which have been kept secret from the foundation of the world
Tell ye the daughter of Sion, Behold, thy King cometh unto thee, meek, and sitting upon an ass
And they took the thirty pieces of silver, the price of him that was valued
quotations.event: Judas's betrayal price and potter's field

hermeneuticalMethods.description: Interpretive approaches used in fulfillment theology

methods.name: Pesher
methods.description: Direct 'this is that' interpretation, common at Qumran. 'This event is the fulfillment of that prophecy.'

methods.name: Typology
methods.description: Historical correspondence between earlier type and later antitype, with escalation (Jesus greater than type)

methods.name: Sensus Plenior
methods.description: Deeper divine meaning in text beyond human author's awareness

methods.name: Midrash
methods.description: Creative Jewish interpretation finding contemporary application in ancient texts

methods.name: Canonical Reading
methods.description: Reading texts in light of whole canon, seeing patterns across Scripture

implications.name: Continuity of Salvation History
implications.description: God's plan is unified from Genesis to Revelation; Jesus is not a departure but the goal

implications.name: Christocentric Hermeneutic
implications.description: The entire Old Testament points forward to Christ as its ultimate meaning

implications.name: Jewish-Christian Unity
implications.description: Christianity emerges from Judaism as its intended fulfillment, not its replacement

implications.name: Divine Sovereignty
implications.description: God's prophetic foreknowledge and control of history demonstrated in fulfillment

implications.name: Apologetic Value
implications.description: Fulfilled prophecy provides evidence for Christian claims about Jesus

implications.name: Scripture's Authority
implications.description: Old Testament remains authoritative as witness to Christ

heroes.name: Matthew the Apostle
heroes.relationship: Gospel author who developed fulfillment theology systematically

heroes.name: Moses
heroes.relationship: Primary Old Testament type fulfilled in Jesus

heroes.name: King David
heroes.relationship: Ancestor whose royal covenant is fulfilled in Jesus

heroes.name: Abraham
heroes.relationship: Ancestor whose covenant of blessing is fulfilled in Jesus

deities.name: Jesus Christ
deities.relationship: The one who fulfills all prophecy

concepts.name: Kingdom of Heaven
concepts.relationship: The reign Jesus inaugurates fulfilling prophetic expectations

query.term: that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophet
Behold a virgin shall be with child
Bethlehem Ephratah little among thousands ruler Israel
Out of Egypt have I called my son
people that walked in darkness have seen a great light
thy King cometh unto thee lowly riding upon an ass
Think not that I am come to destroy the law but to fulfil
he was wounded for our transgressions bruised for our iniquities

sources.title: Gospel of Matthew
sources.author: Matthew (traditional)
sources.citation: All twelve fulfillment formula quotations and five-discourse structure

sources.title: Dialogue with Trypho
sources.author: Justin Martyr
sources.citation: Earliest systematic apologetic using fulfilled prophecy

sources.title: The Use of the Old Testament in the New
sources.author: R. N. Longenecker
sources.citation: Standard scholarly treatment of NT use of OT

sources.title: Matthew's Use of the Old Testament
sources.author: Robert Gundry

fullDescription: Theological framework asserting Jesus Christ fulfills the prophecies, types, and promises of Hebrew Scripture, demonstrated through Matthew's distinctive fulfillment formula and pentateuchal structure
